ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about how to do calculations in multivariable calculus.

I learned the ins and outs of calculus, highly focused on integrating in multiple dimensions. I also learned how effective of a resource office hours was, and that it is ok to change sections if you are not satisfied with the teaching in your original secion.
I learned how to apply calculus to functions of several variables
I learned the basics of multivariable calculus and how to solve the problems we were presented in class. We did not discuss how these skills would be applicable to real-world situations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is very fast paced for those who have never seen the subject before, but it does a good job of forcing students to learn the material.

This might not be unique to multivariable calculus at Yale, but the pacing of the course is just so, so fast. Calculus is also generally not taught in a way that is particularly engaging. This was a very difficult course that consumed a lot of my time, without much satisfaction in what I learned. Again, this seems common to multivariable calculus classes in undergrad generally, but nevertheless it was not an enjoyable experience.
It was not taught well and the tests and problem sets were tough

I think this course is well taught if you have a talented instructor. However, it is sometimes hard to see the purpose of some of the concepts, and it would be more interesting if I really understood why I was learning whatever I learned throughout the course.

The concepts taught in this course should not have been terribly challenging, yet the teaching and student support systems were subpar to say the least. I struggled in a way I was not expecting to, and there was not a lot of help available. All of my friends in the class chose to credit/D/fail or drop it, expressing similar concerns. The only reason I did not do the same was because it is a major prereq.

A strength of the course was the access to out of classroom resources, including peer hours and review sessions. These organized events were beneficial when preparing for exams. A significant weakness of the course is the variance in the quality of teaching between sections. A student's experience entirely depends on their section leader, with some teachers not covering material that others addressed. I spent the majority of my time reviewing class content from the textbook to supplement in-person instruction.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I could recommend this course for those who need to take it for their majors.

Its a requirement for a lot of majors. If you can take the ENAS version of multivariable calculus for your major, it generally seems less stressful while teaching the relevant calculus needed. If you can credit/D/fail the course, thats also a good option.

I would make sure the student has enough time for this course's workload and make sure the student's instructor is talented at teaching this course. Then, and only then, I would tell a student that they should take this course if they are interested in this material.
Absolutely not, there are better multi courses on both the sciences side and the mathematics side. This is the worst class Ive taken so far at Yale.

I would recommend this course if you are required to take a multivariable calculus course. Any student entering the course should be aware that they will need to donate time outside of class to absorb the material. I would also encourage anyone who has a particular interest in multivariable calculus to take the course. If not, another math class may be more enjoyable.
